    char* decode_first_program(const char* n) {
        // n is the input string
        int len = strlen(n);
        // We allocate an output string: the output has at most len characters? 
        // Actually, each input character produces at most one output character? 
        // But the flag might cause two dashes to produce one output? 
        // Actually, the output length is the number of '.' plus the number of complete dashes (each dash that is part of a pair produces one output, and a dash that is alone doesn't produce output until a following character). 
        // But the total output length is the number of tokens: each '.' produces one output, and each dash that is followed by a dash or a dot will eventually produce an output (either 2 for two dashes, or 1 for a dash followed by a dot). 
        // Actually, the output has the same length as the input? Not exactly: 
        //   Example: input ".-" 
        //        i=0: '.' -> output '0' -> output length=1.
        //        i=1: '-' -> because s is false, set s=true -> no output.
        //   So the output is "0", which has length 1, while input has length 2.

        // Therefore, we cannot preallocate with the same length. We'll count the output length? Or we can use a dynamic array.

        // We'll use a buffer of the same length (or even the same length is enough) and then we know the output length will be <= len.

        char* output = (char*)malloc(len+1);   // +1 for null
        int out_index = 0;
        int s = 0;   // false: we use 0 for false, 1 for true.

        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
            if (n[i] == '.') {
                if (s) {
                    output[out_index++] = '1';
                    s = 0;
                } else {
                    output[out_index++] = '0';
                }
            } else { // n[i] == '-'
                if (s) {
                    output[out_index++] = '2';
                    s = 0;
                } else {
                    s = 1;
                }
            }
        }
        output[out_index] = '\0';
        return output;
    }

    long run_second_program(int N) {
        if (N < 0) {
            // The Java program would not have negative, so we set to 0.
            return 0;
        }
        #define MOD 1000000007L
        // Precompute the valid array for last4 strings (4 bases)
        int valid[256] = {0};   // 0: invalid, 1: valid
        const char* bases = "ACGT";

        // We'll iterate over all possible 4^4=256 states.
        for (int c0 = 0; c0 < 4; c0++) {
            for (int c1 = 0; c1 < 4; c1++) {
                for (int c2 = 0; c2 < 4; c2++) {
                    for (int b = 0; b < 4; b++) {
                        int idx = c0*64 + c1*16 + c2*4 + b;
                        char str[5];
                        str[0] = bases[c0];
                        str[1] = bases[c1];
                        str[2] = bases[c2];
                        str[3] = bases[b];
                        str[4] = '\0';

                        // Check for "AGC"
                        if (strstr(str, "AGC") != NULL) {
                            valid[idx] = 0;
                        } else {
                            int ok = 1;
                            // Try the three adjacent swaps
                            for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
                                // swap i and i+1
                                char temp = str[i];
                                str[i] = str[i+1];
                                str[i+1] = temp;
                                if (strstr(str, "AGC") != NULL) {
                                    ok = 0;
                                    break;
                                }
                                // swap back
                                temp = str[i];
                                str[i] = str[i+1];
                                str[i+1] = temp;
                            }
                            valid[idx] = ok;
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        }

        // Now, set up dp[101][64]
        long dp[101][64];   // dp[i][s] for i in [0, N] and s in [0,63]

        // Initialize: when i = N, for every state s, dp[N][s] = 1
        for (int s = 0; s < 64; s++) {
            dp[N][s] = 1;
        }

        // For i from N-1 down to 0
        for (int i = N-1; i >= 0; i--) {
            for (int s = 0; s < 64; s++) {
                dp[i][s] = 0;
                for (int b = 0; b < 4; b++) {
                    int last4_index = s * 4 + b;
                    if (valid[last4_index]) {
                        int s_new = (s % 16) * 4 + b;   // shift state: remove the first base, then add b at the end.
                        dp[i][s] = (dp[i][s] + dp[i+1][s_new]) % MOD;
                    }
                }
            }
        }

        // The initial state is "TTT" -> state = 3*16+3*4+3 = 63
        return dp[0][63];
    }

  Then the third program function:

    void run_third_program(const char* s) {
        // s is the string (the output of the second program: a string of digits)

        // We are going to simulate the moves: 
        //   We need to record the entire path (coordinates at each step)
        //   The path can have up to (length of s + 1) points.

        int len = strlen(s);
        // We allocate two arrays for x and y: size len+1
        int* x_coords = (int*)malloc((len+1) * sizeof(int));
        int* y_coords = (int*)malloc((len+1) * sizeof(int));
        x_coords[0] = 0;
        y_coords[0] = 0;
        int k = 1;   // we have one point at step0

        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
            int x = x_coords[k-1];
            int y = y_coords[k-1];
            // Move based on s[i]
            switch (s[i]) {
                case 'L': 
                    x--;
                    break;
                case 'R':
                    x++;
                    break;
                case 'U':
                    y++;
                    break;
                case 'D':
                    y--;
                    break;
                // For any other character (like digits), we do nothing.
                default:
                    break;
            }
            x_coords[k] = x;
            y_coords[k] = y;
            k++;
        }

        // Now, we have k points (from index0 to index k-1)
        int flag = 1;   // true: OK

        // We check: for i from 0 to k-3, and j from i+3 to k-1
        for (int i = 0; i < k - 3; i++) {
            for (int j = i+3; j < k; j++) {
                int dx = x_coords[i] - x_coords[j];
                int dy = y_coords[i] - y_coords[j];
                if (dx < 0) dx = -dx;
                if (dy < 0) dy = -dy;
                if ((dx <= 1 && dy == 0) || (dy <= 1 && dx == 0)) {
                    flag = 0;
                    break;
                }
            }
            if (!flag) break;
        }

        if (flag) {
            printf("OK\n");
        } else {
            printf("BUG\n");
        }

        free(x_coords);
        free(y_coords);
    }
